Description: Fragment of a limestone egg-and-dart moulding from an echinus. Fragment shows two leaves of rounded early Ionic cymas survive. The treatment of the white and chalky limestone with small holes and solid black curst is rather crude.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'first temple of Apollo'.)
Curator's comments: Together with two other fragments, B397a and 397d, this small fragment corresponds in type, material and crude artistic treatment with the larger fragment B397b, however, not in their measurements. Thus they come from at least two different architectural elements. Moreover, the profile of the cross-section of this fragment is 1 cm higher than B 397b and also the bridge on the under differs. In plan view this fragment does not correspond very closely with fragments B397a and B397c (Koenigs 2007, 317-318). Published (Koenigs 2007, 317f. Cat. 7; Naukratis 1886, 5f, 13 Pl. 3; Dismoor, AAG, 125ff. Fig. 47; Kirchhoff 1988, 197f, No. E 1; Bakker 1999, 51f, Cym. 1)
Bibliographic references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum (B397c)
Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (Cat. no.7c, p.317-318, pl. 7,8,10,12)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.13) (Phase 3)
